title: Migraine Disability Assessment (MIDAS)
description: Quantifies headache-related disability over a 3-month period to guide treatment decisions

parameters.name: missed_work_school
parameters.description: Days in last 3 months missed work or school because of headaches

parameters.name: reduced_work_school
parameters.description: Days in last 3 months productivity at work/school reduced by half or more

parameters.name: missed_household
parameters.description: Days in last 3 months did not do household work because of headaches

parameters.name: reduced_household
parameters.description: Days in last 3 months productivity in household work reduced by half or more

parameters.name: missed_social
parameters.description: Days in last 3 months missed family, social, or leisure activities

result.name: midas_score
result.description: Total MIDAS score indicating headache-related disability

ranges.interpretation: Patient has little or no headache-related disability. Consider simple analgesics and lifestyle modifications. Prophylactic treatment typically not required.
Patient has mild headache-related disability. Consider migraine-specific acute treatments. Discuss prophylaxis if attacks are frequent or disabling.
Patient has moderate headache-related disability. Recommend migraine-specific acute treatments and strongly consider prophylactic treatment to reduce frequency and severity.
Patient has severe headache-related disability. Urgent need for effective acute treatment and prophylaxis. Consider referral to headache specialist if not already under specialist care.

references: Stewart WF, Lipton RB, Kolodner K, Liberman J, Sawyer J. Reliability of the migraine disability assessment score in a population-based sample of headache sufferers. Cephalalgia. 1999 Mar;19(2):107-14; discussion 74.

Stewart WF, Lipton RB, Dowson AJ, Sawyer J. Development and testing of the Migraine Disability Assessment (MIDAS) Questionnaire to assess headache-related disability. Neurology. 2001;56(6 Suppl 1):S20-8.

Stewart WF, Lipton RB, Kolodner KB, Sawyer J, Lee C, Liberman JN. Validity of the Migraine Disability Assessment (MIDAS) score in comparison to a diary-based measure in a population sample of migraine sufferers. Pain. 2000 Oct;88(1):41-52.
formula: MIDAS Score = Q1 + Q2 + Q3 + Q4 + Q5
notes: MIDAS assesses headache impact over the past 3 months (90 days)
Score does not include days counted in previous questions
Can be used to track treatment response over time
Higher scores indicate greater disability and need for more aggressive treatment
The questionnaire also includes two additional questions (A and B) about headache frequency and pain intensity, but these are not included in the total score
